File.Title: An Autoradiographic Study of Projections Ascending From the Midbrain Central Gray, and From the Region Lateral to It, in the Rat

Abstract.S: Ascending projections from the midbrain central gray (CG) and from the region lateral to it were traced in the rat using tritiated amino acid autoradiography.
Leucine or a cocktail of amino acids (leucine, proline, lysine, histidine, and tyrosine) were used as tracers.
In addition to projections within the midbrain, ascending fibers follow three trajectories.

The ventral projection passes through the ventral tegmental region of Tsai and the medial forebrain bundle to reach the hypothalamus, preoptic area, caudoputamen, substantia innominata, stria terminalis, and amygdala.
There are labeled fibers in the diagonal bands of Broca and medial septum, and terminal labeling in the lateral septum, nucleus accumbens, olfactory tubercle, and frontal cortex.
The dorsal periventricular projection terminates in the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei.

The ventral periventricular projection follows the ventral component of the third ventricle into the hypothalamus, passing primarily through the dorsal hypothalamic area and labeling the rostra1 hypothalamus and preoptic area.
Projections from the region lateral to the CG are similar, but exhibit stronger proximal, and weaker distal, projections.
Rostra1 levels of the CG send heavier projections to the fields of Fore1 and the zona incerta, but fewer fibers through the supraoptic decussation, than do caudal levels.
Ascending projections from the CG are both strong and widespread.
Strong projections to the limbic system and the intralaminar thalamic nuclei provide an anatomical substrate for CG involvement in nociception and affective responses.

Introduction.S: Neurons in and adjacent to the mesencephalic central gray (CG) participate in many functional systems.

In particular, data from lesion, electrical stimulation, and microinjection studies support a strong role for CG neurons in nociception (reviewed in Basbaum and Fields, '841, affect and emotional reactions (reviewed in Skultety, '63), and female reproductive behavior (reviewed in Pfaff, '83).
Augmenting physiological and neurochemical evidence for a role of the CG in diverse activities, CG afferents provide an anatomical foundation for proposed functions.

The greatest number of diand telencephalic afferents arise from the ventromedial, dorsal premammillary, and anterior hypothalamic nuclei; the lateral hypothalamus; and the zona incerta (Morrell et al., '81; Beitz, '82; Mantyh, '82b; Marchand and Hagino, '83; Morrell and Pfaff, '83).

Afferents from the brainstem originate primarily in the cuneiform nucleus, substantia nigra, ventral tegmental area, locus coeruleus, parabrachial nuclei, raphe magnus, and the pontine and medullary reticular formation.

Projections from the midbrain CG have been visualized with the Marchi method for degenerating myelin (Bodian, '40; Bucher and Biirgi, '53) and with various modifications of the Nauta method for degenerating axoplasm (Kuypers, '56; Nauta, '58; Nauta and Kuypers, '58; Szentagothai et al., '62; Chi, '70; Hamilton and Skultety, '70; Hamilton, Accepted July 11, 1985.
J.A.
Eberhart's present address is Dept. of Psychology, Carleton College, One North College St., Northfield, MN 55057-4025.
By describing the trajectory of axons emanating from the CG, these studies provide a basis for considering CG efferents.
Yet, the projections demonstrated by these methods may not be entirely representative of CG neurons.

In particular, certain degeneration methods fail to stain finecaliber fibers (Sutin, '66; Heimer, '67; Chi, '70); hence, these methods underestimate the projections of neuronal systems containing such fibers.
Moreover, electrolytic lesions inducing degeneration also damage fibers of passage in the CG; thus, cells outside the CG may contribute to the observed degeneration.

These methodological difficulties may be overcome through the use of tritiated amino acid autoradiography, a technique that indicates projections only from cells at the injection site (Cowan et al., '72; Hendrickson, '75).
Indeed, autoradiogaphy has been used to demonstrate projections from the CG in cats (Ruda, '76) and monkeys (Mantyh, '83c,d), confirming and extending observations made with degeneration techniques.
No autoradiographic demonstration of CG efferents has been published for the rat.
Moreover, despite studies in the cat and monkey, the full range of' CG projections is unknown.
For instance, many studies using retrograde tracing methods report that C!

G neurons project to diverse regions of the brain and spinal cord (e.g., Kuypers and Maisky, '75; Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Ottersen, '81; Luiten et al., '82; Porrino and Goldman-Rakic, '82); not all such projections are observed in extant autoradiog-aphic studies.
Thus, although not indicating the full extent of projections, retrograde tracing studies demonstrate that CG efferents are more widespread than previous autoradiographic studies suggest.
Therefore, in the present study, we have used sensitive autoradiographic techniques to describe in detail projections ascending fi-om the mesencephalic CG of the rat.
Some of the present data have been presented in preliminary form (Eberhart et al., '82).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS

Fifty-four intact adult male or female Long-Evans rats (Charles River, 200-320 g) were used; each was given a single pressure or iontophoretic microinjection of isotope into, or lateral to, the mesencephalic central gray at the superior-, inter-, or inferior collicular level.

Each rat received either an iontophoretic application of tritiated leucine, or a pressure microinjection of tritiated leucine, or a pressure injection of a "cocktail" containing five tritiated amino acids (leucine, proline, lysine, histidine, and tyrosine).
In all cases the isotope was prepared the morning of use, as described below.
Rats were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (Nembutal, Abbott) and positioned in a Kopf stereotaxic instrument.

The scalp was retracted, the head was leveled, and a small hole was drilled in the skull to accommodate either a glass micropipette (for iontophoresis) or the 28-gauge needle of a 1-pl Hamilton syringe (for pressure injections).
The syringe carrier was positioned at a 10" or 15" frontal or lateral angle to avoid damage to the venous sinuses.
Preparation of autoradiograms

For iontophoretic applications (n = 17), tritiated leucine (L-leucine [3,4,5-'HH(N)], 115 Ci/mmol, New England Nuclear) was adjusted to pH = 3.5 with acetic acid and concentrated to 20 pCiip1 in a centrifugal microevaporator (Omicron Industries).
The filled micropipette (tip diameter, 20-35 pm) was slowly lowered into the brain and left undisturbed for 15 minutes.
Thereafter, a continuous anodal current of 1-2 pA was passed for 8-20 minutes using a Midgard High Voltage Precision Current Source.
For pressure injections (n = 13) of 'H-leucine, the isotope was centrifugally evaporated to dryness, immediatdy reconstituted in 5 pl of sterile saline, and loaded into the Hamilton microsyringe.

Fifteen minutes after the injection needle was lowered into the brain, 10 nl(1.7 pCi) of isotope (nominal concentration, 170 pCiip1) was injected; injections were made in increments, with the aid of a microdrive, over 15-20 minutes.

The tritiated cocktail consisted of L-13,4,53H(N)]-leucine (110 or 115 Ci/mmol), L-12,3,4,5-'H]-proline (139 or 160 Ciimmol), L-[4,5-'H(N)]-lysine (68 Ci/mmol), L[3-'H]-histidine (10 Ci/mmol), and L-[ring-3,5-"HI-tyrosine (53 Ci/mmol), all from New England Nuclear.
Immediately before use, equal volumes of these isotopes were pooled and evaporated to a final volume of approximately 5 pl (concentration, 100 pCi/pl).
After the syringe was loaded, the needle was lowered into the brain and left in place 15 minutes.
Thereafter, either 10 nl (1.0 pCi, in 11 rats) or 25 nl (2.5 pCi, in 13 rats) of the cocktail was injected in ten to 15 increments over 1.5-2 hours, respectively.
In all cases, after the application of isotope the micropipette or needle was left in place for 15-20 minutes before being slowly withdrawn, and the scalp was closed with wound clips.

Animals receiving the leucine tracer were perfused either days (pressure injections) or 3 days (iontophoretic applications) after surgery; animals receiving 10 nl of the cocktail were perfused after 6 days, and those receiving 25 nl were perfused after either 6 or 10 days.
Under deep Nembutal anesthesia, animals were cardiac perfused with a gravity-feed system.
Intracardial injection of heparin (200 UPS units in 0.2 ml) was followed by 0.9% saline for 3 minutes (or until the perfusate was entirely clear) and then by 10% formalin for 10 minutes.
Brains were removed from the skull and stored in 10% formalin for at least 1 week before being blocked, cleared, and embedded in Paraplast (Sherwood Medical).
Sections were cut at 6 Km in frontal or sagittal planes on a paraffin microtome (Spencer 820).
Series of four to ten adjacent sections were mounted on precleaned, albumin-coated glass slides, with 60 pm discarded between consecutive slides.
Slides were deparaffinized, stained with Luxol Fast Blue to demonstrate myelinated fibers, and air-dried overnight.
In a darkroom illuminated by a single 60-W bulb behind a Kodak # 2 safelight filter (#152 15251, slides were dipped in Kodak NTB-3 nuclear track emulsion at 43°C.
After drying at room temperature for several hours, slides were packed with desiccant (Driaire) in small, light-tight slide boxes (Clay-Adams).
These boxes were sealed with black tape, covered with desiccant (Drierite), and exposed at 4°C in large lead-lined boxes.
Following exposure periods of 3 months (cocktail tracer) or 1, 3, 5, or 21 months (leucine tracer), slides were developed with Kodak D-19 Developer (16"C, 3 minutes), photofixed, and washed.
The slides were then stained with cresyl violet to indicate cell bodies and coverslipped with Permount (Fisher).
Data analysis and presentation
Autoradiograms were examined under brightfield or darkfield illumination with a Zeiss Universal microscope, and representative sections were drawn with the aid of a microprojector.
The distribution of reduced silver grains in the autoradiograms was charted during systematic examination of sections with brightfield illumination and a 40 x objective lens.
In each section examined, the level of background labeling was evaluated before charting; only labeling distinctly heavier than that over brain areas not receiving projections was recorded on charts.

No attempt was made to chart projections in the immediate area of the injection site; although labeling in this area may represent short-axon projections, possible diffusion of the isotope complicates interpretation of such labeling.
Figure 1 illustrates the maximum extent of the injection site in case CG36, which is representative of cases with 3Hcocktail injections in the CG.
Figure 2 presents the injection site for each of the cases described in this report.

The core of an injection site, indicated in black in the presented charts, is defined as the area in which there are clearly many more silver grains over cell bodies than over the surrounding neuropil.
Around this dense core there is an area where the intensity of labeling over cells diminishes to being equal to that over the neuropil.
This area is circled in Figure 2 and lightly shaded in illustrations of individual cases.
Although the area of more dense labeling may be expected to contribute most heavily to observed projections, the effective area of tracer uptake is not known.

Where there are aggregations of silver grains over bundles of blue-stained fibers cut in cross section, or a series of silver grains over blue fibers in the plane of the section, these fibers are considered labeled.
In illustrations, the density of label not localized to fibers is represented semiquantitatively by small dots.

Although there are instances in which silver grains are clustered around cell bodies, suggesting the possibility of axosomatic contact (e.g., Fig. 4), the existence of synapses cannot be demonstrated by this method.

A more common pattern of labeling is an area of diffuse label, not exclusively localized to stained fibers or cell bodies; such a distribution of silver grains may represent labeling of diffuse fibers, areas of termination, or both.
In many cases the probability of these alternatives may be inferred by examining the trajectory, pattern, and intensity of labeling in adjacent slides.
The autoradiographic procedures used in this study are essentially those previously described for this laboratory (Conrad et al., '74; Conrad and Pfaff '76).
These earlier reports may be consulted for further details of the method.
Anatomical terms are adapted from Paxinos and Watson ('82), supplemented by Konig and Klippel ('74) and Pellegrino et al. ('79).

Results.S: RESULTS
At each of the superior-, inter-, and inferior collicular levels there was at least one case with a robust injection of tracer in the CG, and one with a strong injection centered lateral to the CG.

In general , experiments with cocktails of tritiated leucine , proline , lysine , histidine , and tyrosine revealed stronger patterns of projections than did either pressure or iontophoretic injections of tritiated leucine .
One case with a strong injection of tritiated leucine and a 21month exposure ( CG12 ) exhibited heavy and widespread projections ( Fig . 5 ) .
Among "H-cocktail injections, cases having 6-day survival periods provided clearer labeling of fibers than did those having 10-day survival periods.
All cases exhibited bilateral labeling.
In general , contralateral projections were lighter and less extensive than , but otherwise similar to , ipsilateral projections .
It is likely that some portion of contralateral labeling resulted from the uptake and transport of tracer by a small number of labeled cells contralateral to the bulk of the injection site .

Yet , as there were clear contralateral projections in cases with injection sites restricted to the ipsilateral side , and there were labeled fibers crossing the midline in all cases , at least some contralateral labeling must reflect crossed CG projections .
In each case there was some label along the needle track in the cortex overlying the injection site.
This labeling ranged from very light , not distinctly labeling cells , to moderately strong , contributing projections to the internal capsule , dorsal thalamus , and contralateral cortex .
With the exception of labeling in these structures, we found no relationship between strength of cortical contamination and either the pattern or strength of projections.
It is unlikely that transport of tracer through the ventricular system contributed to the observed projections.

First , injections of tracer into the fourth ventricle labeled the ependyma and the neuropil immediately adjacent to it , but did not result in labeling distant from either the ventricle or the injection site .
Second, injections close to the cerebral aqueduct labeled the ependyma, but this labeling did not extend beyond the immediate region of the injection site (Figs. 1, 2, 31).

Third, when in proximity to the ventricles, the periventricular projection was localized to specific projection systems previously visualized by other methods (e.g., Lindvall and Bjorklund, '74; Lindvall et al., '74) and did not include all periventricular systems.
Fourth, there was a different pattern of projections from different injection sites.
Finally, the distribution of periventricular label did not resemble the diffusion gradient reported after intraventricular injections of "-labeled tracer (cf.
Parent et al., Central gray injections: intercollicular level
Case CG36 Injection.

TTE.S: This animal received a 25 - nl injection of 3Hcocktail tracer ( 2.5 pCi ) in the CG at the level of the nucleus of the trochlear nerve ( IV n ) and was perfused after 10 days .
Autoradiograms were exposed 90 days.

Although there were some labeled cells scattered ventrolateral to the CG and in the dorsal ipsilateral and ventral contralateral CG , the dense portion of the injection site was confined to the ventrolateral central gray ( Fig . 1 ) .

There were silver grains over neurons of the dorsal raphe nucleus and the ipsilateral 111, IV , and mesencephalic V nuclei ; labeling over cells of the cranial nerve nuclei was lighter than that over the surrounding neuropil .
Figure 3 illustrates the ascending projections observed in case CG36.
At the level of the injection site (Fig. 31) there was label over most of the brainstem, being heaviest in the CG and ipsilaterally, ventral and lateral to the injection site.
Virtually no label was found over the cerebral peduncles , middle cerebellar peduncles , or contralateral inferior colliculus .
There were two main projection systems ascending from the neurons of the CG, one ventral and the other periventricular.
Ventral projection.

Labeled fibers of the ventral projection formed a broad arc , extending ventrolaterally from the injection site ( Fig . 31 ) , then ventromedially , coming to lie medially in the mesencephalic reticular formation .
These were joined , in the vicinity of the injection site and more rostrally , by labeled fibers directed ventrolaterally from the injection site ( Fig . 3H ) .

A lighter projection ( best illustrated in Fig . 6G , H ) extended from the lateral CG through the tectum , contributing labeled axons that penetrated the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus ( Fig . 3G ) .

At caudal levels of the interpeduncular nucleus ( IPN ) fibers of the ventral projection were dispersed throughout the region between the IPN and the CG , continuous dorsally with the periventricular projection .
More rostrally, axons of the ventral projection were condensed into a horizontal band that was ventral to, and distinct from, the periventricular projection.

At all levels of the mesencephalic tegmentum , and particularly in the ventral tegmental decussation , labeled axons crossed the midline , coming to lie in the contralateral reticular formation ( Fig . 3H , I ) .
Other labeled fibers crossed the midline in the collicular and posterior commissures ( Fig . 3G , H , I ) , also contributing to the contralateral projection .

At the level of exit of I11 n , diffuse label and labeled fiber bundles filled the region between the medial poles of the medial lemnisci , heavily labeling the ventral tegmental area of Tsai ( VTA ) , as well as the red , paranigral , and the interfascicular nuclei .
In this region , as throughout the mesencephalic reticular formation , it was not clear whether , in addition to fibers of passage , terminals were also present .
The IPN was lightly and diffusely labeled, with slightly heavier labeling in the dorsocaudal aspect and where the fasciculus retroflexus joins.
More rostrally , a few labeled fibers followed the course of the fasciculus retroflexus , perhaps contributing to light labeling in the lateral habenula ( Fig . 3F ) .
Labeled axons were also found bilaterally along the dorsolateral border of the mammillary bodies .
These may contribute to the light labeling of the mammillary bodies, which was heavier ventrally and laterally.
The ventral projection passed primarily through the VTA and less strongly through the area just dorsal to the mammillary bodies .

Fewer axons were distributed laterally , in the substantia nigra ( pars compacta and reticulata ) , zona incerta , and the region of the peripeduncular nucleus at the dorsal extent of the cerebral peduncle ( Fig . 3G ) .
There was also an aggregation of labeled fibers just dorsal to the medial lemniscus , continuous laterally with label in the lateral geniculate nucleus .
More rostrally , axons of the ventral projection joined the medial forebrain bundle ( MFB ) to extend throughout the lateral hypothalamic and preoptic regions ( Fig . 3D - F ; cf .
case CG12: Fig. 5B).

In the hypothalamus , label from the ventral projection ( in the MFB ) was continuous with that from the ventral part of the periventricular projection ( in the dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus and dorsal hypothalamic area ) .

At the level of the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus ( VMN ) , labeled fibers of the ventral projection were found in the MFB ; dorsolateral to it , penetrating the ventral aspect of the internal capsule ( in the region of the entopeduncular nucleus ) ; and dorsal to the internal capsule , in the ventral zona incerta ( Fig . 3F ) .
Here , as more rostrally ( Fig . 3E ) , numerous labeled fibers passed through the supraoptic decussation to reach the caudoputamen and amygdala .
There were labeled fibers and apparent terminal labeling bilaterally in the amygdala , with strongest labeling in the central nucleus , and little or no labeling in the cortical and medial nuclei .

Labeled fibers were also found in the lateral aspect of the ventral stria terminalis ( Fig . 7A ) , continuous with heavy label in both the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( BNST ) ( Fig . 3D , E ) and the central nucleus of the amygdala ( Fig . 3F ) .
This label could have been transported via the central nucleus of the amygdala ( see De Olmos , ' 72 ) or through the BNST .
The mediobasal hypothalamus received few projections , with only light labeling of the VMN and arcuate nucleus .
At the level of the anterior hypothalamic area ( AHA ) and preoptic area ( POA ) there were no clear borders between the ventral and periventricular projections ( Fig . 3D , E ) .

There were labeled fibers and apparent terminal labeling throughout the caudoputamen that was continuous with , but lighter than , labeling in the ventral pallidum , fundus striati , substantia innominata , and anterior amygdaloid area ( Fig . 3B - E ) .

Light , diffuse labeling extended laterally from the ventral hypothalamus to the ipsilateral primary olfactory cortex , and a few labeled fibers lay in the contralateral external capsule ( Fig . 3D , E ) .
Heavily labeled fibers were found medial to the medial border of the internal capsule , stretching from the region of the MFB to the BNST , which was heavily labeled ( Fig . 3C - E ) .
Additionally , diagonally oriented fibers continuous with label in the anterior amygdaloid area were situated ventromedial to , and in the ventromedial aspect of , the internal capsule ( Fig . 3D ) .
In this and other cases there was light label throughout most of the AHA and POA.
At this level , rostrally directed fibers of the ventral projection were concentrated in the ventrolateral AHA and the adjacent medial portion of the lateral hypothalamic area ( Fig . 3E ) .
These fibers occupied the same position in the POA ( Fig . 3D ) .
Some of these fibers projected through the diagonal bands of Broca ( DBB ) to the medial and lateral septum ( Fig . 3C ) .

In addition to labeled fibers , there was terminal labeling in DBB and perisomatic label in the lateral septum ( Fig . 4A , B ), particularly in the dorsomedial region and just medial to the third ventricle .
Other fibers from this bundle provided terminal labeling to the olfactory tubercle , and to a small , circumscribed region of the dorsal nucleus accumbens ( Fig . 3B ) .
StiIl other of these fibers projected through the taenia tecta and forceps minor of the corpus callosum and provided terminal labeling to the medial aspect of the frontal cortex ( Fig . 3A - C ) .
Periventricular projection.
Labeled axons of the periventricular projection extended rostrally from the rostra1 border of the injection site ( Fig . 3H , I ) .
These fibers were found throughout the CG and were particularly numerous ventrally ( Fig . 3H ) .
Fewer labeled fibers were found just lateral to the CG , and labeling was less intense in nuclei of I11 n and nucleus Darkschewitsch than it was in adjacent areas of the CG .
More rostrally , as the cerebral aqueduct elongates into the third ventricle , these axons were more dispersed and continued to penetrate the entire periventricular area ( Fig . 3G ) .

At the mesencephalic - diencephalic junction , where the third ventricle bifurcates into dorsal and ventral components , approximately equal numbers of labeled fibers accompanied each component : some fibers were directed rostrally , into the thalamus , whereas others were oriented ventrally , toward the hypothalamus ( cf . case CG12 : Fig . 5A ) .
These components of the periventricular projection are described in turn.

Axons of the dorsal periventricular projection projected to and through the midline thalamic nuclei : there were bundles of labeled fibers and strong to moderate labeling in the paraventricular ( including posterior and anterior subdivisions ) , intermediodorsal , and interanteromedial nuclei ( Fig . 3F ) .
Labeled fibers from the dorsal projection also joined the internal medullary lamina , labeling the central medial , paracentral , and centrolateral nuclei ( Fig . 3F ) .

The mediodorsal nucleus ( including the lateral subdivision ) was only lightly labeled , with a few lightly labeled fibers connecting the ipsilateral mediodorsal nucleus and the medial division of the lateral habenula ( cf . case CG43 : Fig . 6F ) .
The ventrobasal complex was virtually unlabeled .
Terminal labeling was present in the lateroposterior ( LP ) and laterodorsal ( LD ) nuclei .

Although cortical contamination contributed to labeling in the ipsilateral LD ( Fig : . 3F ) and pwhaps in LP ( see below ) , these nuclei were labeled bilaterally , suggesting that they also received label from the ( bilateral ) dorsal periventricular projection .
The anteroventral nucleus was labeled , but the anterodorsal and paratenial nuclei were unlabeled .
With the exception of the medial portion , over which light and diffuse label extended from hypothalamus to dorsal thalamus , the nucleus gelatinosus was also unlabeled ( Fig . 3F ) .
Additionally , there was label over the rhomboid and reuniens nuclei ; the source of this labeling could be the dorsal or the ventral periventricular projection .
The intensity of thalamic label diminished rostrally (Fig. 3E,F).
Labeled axons in the ventral periventricular projection followed the third ventricle to the region of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus .
Some of these fibers may contribute to the light labeling observed in the lateral and ventral aspects of the mammillary bodies ( Fig . 3G ) .

However , most of these fibers passed through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus , from which they dispersed in three directions : ( 1 ) Axons in the smallest component lightly labeled the narrow region medial to the dorsal and ventral premammillary nuclei and lateral to the arcuate nucleus , as well as a narrow band along the ventral surface of the brain .
( 2 ) A somewhat stronger component of axons extended ventrolaterallv from the posterior hvuothalamic nucleus .
" - Some of these fibers mingled with fibers of the mammillothalamic tract , perhaps contributing very light label to this tract .
Other fibers were directed to the ventrolateral aspect of the brainstem , lightly labeling the lateral portions of the dorsal and ventral premammillary nuclei en route .
Perisomatic accumulations of silver grains , possibly axosomatic endings , were observed around cells lying ventral to the ventral premammillary nucleus .

( 3 ) By far the strongest component of the ventral periventricular projection extended rostrally through the hypothalamic dorsomedial nucleus and particularly through the dorsal hypothalamic area ( Fig . 3F ) .
This loose bundle of labeled fibers was continuous ventrolaterally with fibers from the ventral projection ( in the MFB ) , perhaps contributing to the MFB .
At the level of the VMN , labeled axons in the dorsal hypothalamic area were also continuous with lighter labeling in the zona incerta and that just dorsal to the third ventricle .

In several instances , the trajectory followed by labeled axons in the hypothalamus and the source of diffuse labeling were not precisely determinable , The hypothalamic periventricular nucleus ( PVN ) received a moderately light projection , except for the magnocellular subdivision , which was less heavily labeled than its surround .
The supraoptic nuclei were lightly labeled , but the suprachiasmatic nuclei were unlabeled ( Fig . 3D , E ) .
Throughout the hypothalamus , and particularly more rostrally , labeled fibers followed the course of the fornix ( Fig . 3D - F ) .
These fibers may have contributed label to the septum and preoptic area , and very light label to the fimbria .
Additionally, dorsoventrally oriented fibers from either the dorsal or the ventral periventricular projection lay in the midline at the level of the AHA (Fig. 3E).
These fibers were continuous with the diffuse label and labeled fibers located between the fornix and the third ventricle ( Fig . 3D ) .
Possible cortical contamination.
Figure 3 illustrates the contribution of cortical contamination to the observed pattern of labeling.
Caudal to Figure 3F a small number of labeled fibers crossed from the ipsilateral cortex , via the corpus callosum , to the contralateral dorsomedial cortex .
At the level illustrated , labeled fibers extended ventrolaterally from the ipsilateral cortical labeling to the dorsal internal capsule .
More rostrally , some labeled axons passed medially from the ipsilateral corpus callosum , just ventral to the stria terminalis , and invaded the LD and LP thalamic nuclei .

Results.S: Case CGL2 Injection.

TTE.S: This animal received a pressure injection ( 10 nl , 1.7 pCi ) of 3H - leucine tracer centered in the lateral CG , just caudal to the nucleus of I11 n ( Fig . 2 ) , and was perfused after 2 days .
Cortical contamination was light (Fig. 5A) and apparently did not contribute to extracortical labeling.
In case CG12, projections observed in sections exposed for 3 and 21 months were comparable to those described above for case CG36.
Figure 5 presents two charts of sagittal sections exposed for 21 months.
Observations from this case confirmed and extended the description provided above and indicated the potential usefulness of long exposure periods.
Ventral projections.
Figure 5B illustrates the course of the robust ventral projection from the CG.
As in case CG36 , many labeled fiber bundles in the dorsal midbrain were oriented laterally, whereas most of those in the tegmentum were directed rostrally and ventrally.
These fibers formed two particularly strong bundles just dorsal and just ventral to the superior cerebellar peduncle .
The rostral continuation of the ventral projection lay in the lateral hypothalamic area , with the dorsal extent of these fibers determined by the ventral border of the thalamus ( Fig . 5B ) .
There were many labeled fibers in the supraoptic decussation and labeled axons oriented in a mediolateral direction in the ventral part of the lateral hypothalamic area .
More rostrally , some labeled fibers left the MFB , following the course of the stria terminalis and heavily labeling the BNST .
Others projected to more rostral areas , including the lateral preoptic area , ventral pallidum , and nucleus accumbens .
A few labeled axons were also directed toward the olfactory bulb .

Lateral to the plane indicated by this section there was a strong projection through the area dorsal to the optic tract into the substantia innominata , with labeling in the central nucleus of the amygdala .
Additionally , numerous labeled fibers were directed dorsally into the forceps minor of the corpus callosum .
As suggested by Figure 5B (see also below), thalamic labeling areas, but not in was generally found in intrafascicular well-defined nuclear regions.
PeriuentrLcular projection.
Figure 5A indicates the strength of the periventricular projection and illustrates its division into dorsal and ventral components .

This figure also shows that the medial part of the ventral projection in case CG12 conformed to that of case CG36 : in both brains there were many labeled fibers dorsal to , but only light label in , the IPN .
Moreover, with the exception of the caudal aspect of the mammillary bodies, the ventral mammillary bodies and VMN were essentially unlabeled.
At the caudal border of the thalamus , labeled axons of the dorsal periuentricular projection were directed laterally , out of the plane of the section ( Fig . 5A ) .

Strongly labeled fibers were present in the posterior periventricular nucleus and in the central medial nucleus of the thalamus ; more laterally , there were labeled fibers in the lateral geniculate nucleus .
The ventral thalamus and the mediodorsal , paratenial , and anteromedial thalamic nuclei received little or no labeling .
There was light label in the lateral , but not the medial , habenula .

Many labeled fibers of the ventral periventricular projection were also directed laterally at the level of the caudal diencephalon ; however , clear labeling from this projection was evident just dorsal to the third ventricle ( Fig . 5A ) .
Somewhat more laterally , fibers in the hypothalamus lay dorsal to the VMN , but extended ventrally into the AHA just rostral to the VMN .
There were fibers crossing the midline in the supraoptic decussation , and light labeling in the lateral septum , taenia tecta , and olfactory tubercle .
In case CG36 the source of labeled fibers located medially and oriented dorsoventrally at the level of the AHA ( Fig . 3E ) was uncertain .
The pattern of labeling in Figure 5A suggested that this label arrived via the ventral, rather than the dorsal, periventricular projection.

Results.S: Other cases Two additional animals received injections of tracer in the CG at the intercollicular level.

TTE.S: Case CG8 (Fig. 2) received a 10-nl pressure injection (1.7 yCi) of 3H-proline (2day survival, 150-day exposure).
The injection site was small and restricted to the CG , with many labeled fibers radiating from the CG at the level of the injection site .

Results.S: Although the pattern of observed projections conformed to that described above, both contralateral and distant projections in case CG8 were only lightly labeled.

TTE.S: Case CG41 (Fig. 2) received a 25-1-11 injection (2.5 pCi) of 3H-cocktail (10-day survival, 90-day exposure).
The injection site was very large , extending well into the mesencephalic reticular formation .
Although no transport of cortical contamination was observed , there was label in the medial cortex of the frontal pole .

Results.S: The pattern of projections in case CG41 was similar to that described for case CG36, but considerably stronger bilaterally over both the ventral and periventricular trajectories .
Central gray injections: inferior collicular level
CaYe CG35 Injection.

TTE.S: Twenty - five nanoliters ( 2.5 yCi ) of 3H - cocktail tracer was injected into the CG at the level of the nucleus of N n ( 10 - day survival , 90 - day exposure ) .
The injection site was centered in the CG , but extended ventrolaterally into the cuneiform nucleus and slightly into the ipsilateral inferior colliculus ( Fig . 2 ) .
It labeled neurons of the dorsal raphe nucleus and nuclei of the 111, IV , and mesencephalic V nerves .

Moderately heavy contamination of the cerebral cortex by the injection needle contributed to labeling in the ipsilateral internal capsule , hippocampal formation , LP and LD thalamic nuclei , and the contralateral cerebral cortex .

The projections observed in this case resembled the pattern of projections described and illustrated for cases CG36 (Fig. 3) and CG12 (Fig. 5); therefore, only deviations from that pattern are presented here.
At the level of the injection site , a smaIl number of labeled fibers radiated dorsolaterally into the ipsilateral inferior colliculus .
Other labeled fibers were found in the commissure of the inferior colliculus .
These fibers contributed to a contralateral projection that was lighter and avoided the inferior colliculus, but was otherwise similar to that found ipsilaterally.
Ventral projection.
Although the ventral projection system was not so robust as in case CG36, the tectal component of this projection was clear.
Labeled fibers swept laterally and dorsolaterally from the rostral CG , aggregating just medial to the medial geniculate nucleus .
These fibers extended to the area of the peripeduncular nucleus and apparently to the narrow band of label just dorsal to the medial lemniscus .
Some of these fibers appeared to be directed dorsolaterally to the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus .
By contrast , labeled axons in the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus seemed to follow a more direct , dorsolateral path from the CG .
More rostrally , there were fewer labeled fibers in the MFB than in the periventricular projection .
In the amygdala , there was labeling , not only in the central nucleus , but also light labeling in the basomedial and basolateral nuclei .
The bed nucleus of the stria terminalis was strongly labeled bilaterally .
However , at AHA and POA levels there were considerably fewer labeled fibers along the ventromedial border of the internal capsule than in case CG36 ( cf .
Fig. 3D,E).
Moreover , in case CG35 apparent terminal labeling in the caudoputamen was concentrated dorsomedially .

This pattern was especially clear rostral to the anterior commissure , where distinct label in the caudoputamen was present only in the area dorsolateral , and just lateral , to the lateral ventricle ( cf .
Fig. 3C,D).
Unlike case CG36, case CG35 also exhibited distinct labeling in the ventral and ventromedial cortex , dorsal to the rhinal fissure .
This cortical labeling was evident at, and rostral to, the level indicated in Figure 3A.
Periuentricular projection.
The dorsal periventricular projection was strong.

In addition to the thalamic labeling described for case CG36, there was light label in the anteromedial nucleus and in the dorsal part of the posterior thalamic nucleus ; moderate label over the anterior pretectal area ; and heavier label over the parafascicular thalamic nucleus .

In the intermediodorsal nucleus , as in the dorsal part of the rostral CG , there were several instances in which aggregations of silver grains were in close proximity to cells , suggesting axosomatic connections .
The ventraEperiuentricular projection was very similar to that described for case CG36, with few additions.
In case CG35 axons in the ventral periventricular system apparently contributed to the thalamic radiations at the level of the VMN .
Moreover , the lateral septum was heavily labeled , with numerous instances of perisomatic labeling ( Fig . 4B ) .

Results.S: Other cases Three other rats received applications of leucine centered in the CG at the inferior collicular level .
Slides from two cases (2and 3-day survival, 90and 150-day exposure) with small injection sites produced projections that were too weak to trace beyond the vicinity of the injection.
In one case slides were exposed for 21 months and confirmed the projections described above, particularly that the periventricular projection was stronger than the ventral projection.
Central gray injections: superior collicular level
Case CG43 Injection.

TTE.S: This animal received a 10 - nl ( 1.0 pCi ) injection of 3H - cocktail tracer centered in the CG at the level of the medial geniculate nucleus ( 6 - day surviva, 90 - day exposure ) .

At the injection site , labeling over neurons of I11 n was heavy ( although much lighter than over the surrounding area ) , resulting in strongly labeled fibers bilaterally in the tract of 111 n ( Fig . 6H ) .
The injection site was large , extending beyond the lateral border of the CG and into the ventral contralateral CG .
Only light cortical contamination was present ( Fig . 6E , F ) .
At and rostral to the level of the injection numerous labeled fibers crossed the midline in the commissure of the superior colliculus and in the posterior commissure ( Fig . 6G , H ) .
Together with labeled fibers decussating in the tegmentum , these fibers contributed to a robust contralateral projection .
Ventral projection.

Ipsilaterally , labeled axons of the ventral projection took three paths from the injection site : ( 1 ) many labeled fibers radiated from the lateral CG , following the ventral arc described for other cases ( Fig . 6H )

( 2 ) Other fibers were directed ventrally from the rostral CG , then via the area between the medial lemniscus and the substantia nigra , apparently to the peripeduncular region . ( 3 ) Still other labeled fibers extended from the lateral and laterodorsal aspects of the injection site and collected just medial to the medial geniculate nucleus .
This pattern was evident on the contralateral side in Figure 6H, and was heavier on the ipsilateral side in more rostral sections.
The aggregation of intensely labeled fibers just medial to the medial geniculate nucleus more rostrally gave off fibers that were directed ventrally and ventromedially.
Some of these fibers lay just dorsal to the medial lemniscus , whereas others penetrated the medial lemniscus and lay in the region between the medial lemniscus and the substantia nigra .
Because of the density of label in the ventromedial tegmentum, the destination of these fibers was uncertain.

As in other cases , the most dense labeling in this region was just ventral to the medial lemniscus and just dorsal to the substantia nigra , with a band of distinctly lighter labeling separating these areas .

The more dorsal band of labeled fibers was continuous with labeled fibers in the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus ; the more ventral band of labeled axons was continuous with label in the peripeduncular nucleus .

Some of the labeled fibers lying just medial to the medial geniculate nucleus projected just lateral to the dorsal border of the cerebral peduncle and into the region between the cerebral peduncle and the optic tract , which was continuous , more rostrally , with the supraoptic decussation .
At the level of the rostral mammillary bodies , a few labeled fibers were in the fornix .
These fibers appeared to arise from fibers located along the dorsolateral border of the mammillary bodies.
With several exceptions (below), the rostral trajectory of the ventral projection in case CG43 (superior colliculus) was similar to that in case CG36 (intercollicular).
In the hypothalamus , differences were primarily in the strength of projections .

At the level of the VMN , case CG43 exhibited lighter labeling in the VMN , MFB ( especially ventrolaterally ) , supraoptic decussation , amygdala ( particularly the central nucleus ) , and stria terminalis ( Fig . 6F ) .
However , labeling in the zona incerta was heavier than in case CG36.

At the level of the AHA , although the central nucleus of the amygdala contained both diffuse label and labeled fibers , labeling in case CG43 was generally lighter than in previously described cases .
There was only light label in the caudoputamen and ventrolateral AHA , but heavier labeling in the MFB ( Fig . 6E ) .
An even more restricted distribution of label was evident at the level of the POA (Fig. 6D).

In case CG43 only the MFB was strongly labeled at this level , with light labeling of the ventral pallidum , substantia innominata , and bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , but little or no labeling in the lateral septum .
A major difference between cases was the strength of labeling in the DBB in case CG43 ( Fig . 6C ) .
There were heavily labeled fibers and aggregations of perisomatic label in both ventral ( Fig . 7B , C ) and dorsal ( Fig . 7D ) divisions of the DBB .
The marked decrease in the strength of labeling rostral to the DBB suggested that this structure was a significant terminal region .
More rostrally , there was light label in the ipsilateral nucleus accumbens and the contralateral external capsule ( Fig . 6B ) .
Additionally , labeled fibers were found bilaterally in the rostral portions of the medial and lateral septa1 nuclei and in the taenia tecta .
At the frontal pole no labeling was present in the medial cortex ( Fig . 6A ) ; however , a few clearly labeled fibers were present in the contralateral olfactory tubercle .

This labeling seemed to arise from fibers that crossed the midline in the supramammillary decussation ( Fig . 6G ) and ascended in the contralateral ventrolateral MFB ( see , especially , Fig . 6E ) .
Periventricular projection.
There were many labeled fibers following the fasciculus retroflexus .
These fiber bundles extended rostrally , surrounded the anterior pretectat area , and contributed to labeling in the LP , mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, and lateral habenula ( Fig . 6F , G ) .
The stria medularis was unlabeled (Fig. 6E).

With the addition of parafascicular labeling and label in the posterior and ventrolateral thalamic nuclei the pattern of thalamic labeling in case CG43 corresponded to that of case CG36 ( Fig . 6 E - G ) .
Cortical contamination contributed to light labeling of the ipsilateral dorsal posterior , ventrolateral , LD , and LP thalamic nuclei .
With a few exceptions, the ventral periventricular projection followed the pattern of case CG36.
At the level of the mammillary bodies , labeled fibers in the posterior hypothalamic nucleus were continuous with those in Forel_s fields , where labeling was stronger than in the MFB ( Fig . 6G ) .
A few labeled fibers ventral to the posterior hypothalamic nucleus joined the mammillothalamic tract .

At hypothalamic levels , the zona incerta was more heavily labeled than in previous cases , and labeled fibers connected the zona incerta with the ventral periventricular projection ( in the dorsal hypothalamic area ) ( Fig . 6F ) .
At the level of the VMN , both fibers in the zona incerta and those in the dorsal hypothalamic area contributed to the thalamic radiations .
In the rostral hypothalamus , labeled fibers from the zona incerta dispersed , extending over the medial internal capsule and into the ventral pallidum and substantia innominata .

Other cases Two additional animals received injections of periventricular 3H - co ~ ktail centered in the CG at the superior collicular level ( 25and 10 - nl injections , 6 - day survival , 90day exposure ) .
The injection site of case CG55 (25-111 injection) was strong, but smaller than that of case CG43 (Fig. 2); cortical contamination was robust.

Projections in case CG55 were similar to those of case CG43, with the following exceptions : ( 1 ) the DBB were not so heavily labeled . ( 2 ) There was no projection to the contralateral olfactory tubercle

( 3 ) Labeling was heavier in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , substantia innominata , ventral pallidum , nucleus accumbens , dorsomedial caudoputamen , and in the ventromedial frontal cortex ( just dorsal to the olfactory tubercle ) .

The injection in case CG49 ( 10 - nl injection ) was diffuse and large , covering most of the ipsilateral CG and part of the contralateral CG with light label , but not extending beyond the CG ( Fig . 2 ) .
This case exhibited very strong cortical contamination.
The pattern of labeling in case CG49 was similar to that in case CG55, with the addition of labeling in the medial habenula .

Results.S: Lateral injections: intercollicular level
Case CG38 injection.

TTE.S: In this animal 25 nl ( 2.5 WCi ) of 3H - cocktail tracer was injected lateral to the ventral CG at the intercollicular level ( Fig . 8G ) .
Survival time was 10 days, and autoradiograms were exposed 90 days.
The injection site included a small number of heavily labeled cells in the ipsilateral CG and lightly labeled neurons of the ipsilateral I11 n and mesencephalic V n .
Neurons of the ipsilateral IV n were either unlabeled or only very lightly labeled .
Moderate cortical contamination was present , contributing to light labeling of the contralateral medial cortex and the ipsilateral hippocampal formation and dorsal thalamus ( Fig . 8D ) .
The general pattern of projections followed that described for case CG36, with two major differences.
First , much of the labeling was restricted to the mesencephalic reticular formation ( Fig . 8F , G ) , with generally lighter labeling more rostrally .

Second , the injection contributed relatively few labeled fibers to the dorsal component of the periventricular projection , resulting in particularly light labeling in the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei ( Fig . 8D ) .
Although the injection site was entirely confined to the ipsilateral brainstem , there was a distinct contralateral projection .

Numerous labeled fibers crossed the midline in the commissure of the superior colliculus and distributed to the dorsal contralateral reticular formation and deep layers of the superior colliculus ( Fig . 8F , G ) .

Throughout the rostral midbrain a substantial number of labeled fibers also projected to the contralateral side by way of the dorsal , and particularly the ventral , tegmental decussation ( Fig . 8F ) .

At the level of the injection site ( Fig . 8G ) , there were many heavily labeled fiber bundles in the medial contralateral reticular formation , contributing to a descending projection to the medulla .
Ventral projection.
The ventral projection in case CG38 differed from that previously described.

At the love1 of the IPN , the heaviest labeling ( with the exception of decussating fibers ) was lateral to and in the CG ( Fig . 8F ) , rather than in an arc dorsal to the IPN and mammillary bodies ( cf .
Figs. 3H, 5A, 6H).
As in other cases , labeling extended dorsolaterally from the VTA , through the region between the medial lemniscus and substantia nigra , to the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus .
At this level , labeled fibers extended along the dorsal brainstem from the periventricular gray to the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus ( Fig . 8E ) .
Both the substantia nigra and the lateral geniculate nucleus received moderately light labeling .
In the hypothalamus ( Fig . 8D ) , there were a moderate number of labeled fibers in the supraoptic decussation and labeling in the anterior amygdaloid area and the central nucleus of the amygdala .
However , throughout the hypothalamus the ventral projection was clearly lighter than in cases with injections centered in the CG ( cf .
Figs . 3F , 6F ) : there were relatively few labeled axons in the MFB , zona incerta , and stria terminalis .
As in previous cases, the PVN, AHA, and VMN were lightly labeled.
At more rostral levels , much of the label was in the lateral preopt ic area , ventral pallidum , substantia innominata , just medial to the internal capsule , and in the medial cortex ( Fig . 3 ) .
There was less label in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , the DBB , and the dorsomedial caudoputamen ( Fig .
Rostra1 to Figure 8A , very light labeling was found in the lateral septum , taenia tecta , and ventral cortex , just dorsal to the olfactory tubercle .
Periuentricular projection.
The rostral CG was labeled throughout (Fig. 8F,G), but this labeling was considerably lighter than in cases with injections of tracer in the CG (cf.
Figs. 3G,H, 5A, 6H).
At the level of the VMN ( Fig . 8D ) , dorsal periventricular labeling in the centrolateral thalamic nucleus was continuous with labeling in LD and LP , which resulted from cortical Contamination .
Although it was considerably weaker than in cases with injections centered in the CG, the ventral periventricular projection followed the description provided above.

Results.S: Case CG51 Injection.

TTE.S: This animal received a 25-nl(2.5 pCi) injection of H-cockt,ail tracer and was perfused after 6 days; autoradiograms were exposed 90 days.
The injection site was centered ventrolateral to the CG at the intercollicular level and was very large (Fig. 2).

The area of heavy cellular labeling included the most lateral portion of the CG and reached the lateral extent of the brainstem , primarily labeling the deep mesencephalic nucleus ( Paxinos and Watson 82 ) .
Caudally , there were heavily labeled cells throughout most of the cuneiform nucleus .
There was considerable cortical contamination contributing label to the contralateral mediodorsal cortex and ipsilateral dorsal thalamus .
Ventral projection.
With the exception of the following differences, the ventral projection was similar to that of CG38.

At the level of the injection site many labeled fiberij crossed the midline in the collicular commissure , extended to a point just medial to the contralateral inferior colliculus , then projected ventrally , reflecting the arc found ipsilaterally .
More rostrally , labeling in the VMN was distinctly stronger than in the surrounding hypothalamus ( Fig . 9B , cf .
Figs. 3F, 6F, 8D).
Moreover , there was very strong labeling in the supraoptic decussation bilaterally .
This label contributed not only to the caudoputamen but also - via a distinct dorsomedial band - to the perifornical region and the dorsal AHA ( Fig . 9A ) .
There was light label in the dorsal fornix , optic chiasm , medial cortex , and medial amygclaloid nucleus and labeled fibers crossing the midline in the supraoptic decussation .
Periuentricular projection.
There was labeling in the CG, with distinctly heavier bands of label, bilaterally, extending from the cerebral aqueduct to the dorsolateral border of the CG.
The dorsal periventricular projection lightly labeled the lateral margin of the anteroventral thalamic nuclei bilaterally ( Fig . 9A ) .
In other respects the dorsal and ventral periventricular projections were light , but followed the pattern of case CG36.

Results.S: Lateral injections: inferior collicular level
Case CG39 Injection.

TTE.S: Twenty-five nanoliters (2.5 pCi) of 'H-cocktail was injected lateral to the CG at the inferior collicular level.
Survival time was 10 days and exposure time was 90 days.
The injection site was centered caudal to the level of IV n ( Fig . 2 ) , just lateral to the cells of mesencephalic V n , which were labeled .
This region corresponds to the cuneiform nucleus (Paxinos and Watson, '82).

There were some heavily labeled cells in the lateral CG , with a few very lightly labeled cells as far medially as the midline of the ventral CG , perhaps including some cells of the dorsal raphe nucleus .
There were also labeled cells in the medial inferior colliculus and in the medial and lateral subdivisions of the parabrachial nucleus ( Pellegrino et al . , ' 79 ) .
Contamination from the injection needle was present, but did not project beyond the cortex.
With the exception of divergences described below, the pattern of projections was similar to that of case CG38.
Ventral projection.

The aggregation of labeled fibers just medial to the medial geniculate nucleus was strong , apparently projecting to the area of the peripeduncular nucleus and the region just dorsal to the medial lemniscus .
The MFB , zona incerta , and stria terminalis were moderately labeled .

At the level of the preoptic area , the heaviest hypothalamic labeling was in the ventromedial MFB , continuous with strong labeling in the perifornical region ( presumably of ventral periventricular origin ) .
There was robust labeling in the ventral part of the vertical DBB , lighter labeling in the central amygdaloid nucleus , and very light labeling in the medial cortex .
As in case CG51, the VMN received a distinctly stronger projection than did the surrounding hypothalamus , and there was label in the medial amygdaloid nucleus .
Another similarity with case CG51 was the very strongly labeled fibers in the supraoptic decussation .
Some of these fibers projected to the perifornical region of the AHA ( cf .
Fig . 9A ) , whereas others remained dorsal to the optic tract and more rostrally decussated in the supraoptic decussation .
The perifornical component may contribute to strongly labeled fibers traversing the triangular septal nucleus and to moderate labeling in the lateral septal nucleus .
Periuentricular projection.
The CG was labeled bilaterally , with lighter label in the contralateral ventrolateral quadrant , where the dorsal longitudinal fasciculus of Schutz is located .
The parafascicular thalamic nucleus was well labeled , as was the lateral border of the anteroventral thalamic nucleus ( cf .
Fig. 9A).
The ventral periuentricular projection was very strong , perhaps contributing to label in the PVN and periventricular hypothalamic nuclei .

Results.S: Lateral injections: superior collicular level
Case CG.52 Injection.

TTE.S: Twenty - five nanoliters ( 2.5 pCi ) of 3H - cocktail tracer was injected lateral to the CG at the superior collicular level .
Survival time was 6 days and exposure time was 90 days.
The injection site was large , occupying the region between the CG and the medial border of the medial geniculate nucleus ( Fig . 2 ) .
Labeled neurons were present in the ventral part of the anterior pretectal area ( Paxinos and Watson , ' 82 ) as far rostrally as the level of the caudal mammillary bodies .
The injection site extended caudally to the level of the caudal border of the red nucleus .
Cortical contamination contributed to labeling of the hippocampal formation , dorsal ipsilateral thalamus , and dorsal contralateral cortex .
With the exceptions noted below, the pattern of projections resembled that of Case CG36.
Ventral projection.
The ventral projection was weak , with a moderate number of labeled fibers in the supraoptic decussation , and relatively few in the lateral MFB and stria terminalis .

There was a moderate projection throughout the caudoputamen , but little or no labeling of the medial hypothalamus , bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, lateral septum , DBB , or medial frontal cortex .
In the amygdala , there was light labeling in the caudal aspect of the central nucleus and in the rostral part of the cortical nucleus .
Just rostral to the injection site, there was a pattern of robust Projections not observed in other cases.

At t , hr IWPI ~ " ~ ~ . - _ of the manimillary bodies , both labeling in the zona incerta and fields of Forel , and that extending directly rostral from the injection site , were continuous with heavy label surrounding the fasciculus retroflexus .
More rostrally , this parafascicular label extended medially , into the caudal part of the central medial thalamic nucleus , which was strongly labeled ipsilaterally .
Also at this level , the heaviest labeling in the zona incerta was medial , continuous with heavy labeling in the thalamic reuniens nucleus .

Further rostrally , apparent terminal labeling and heavily labeled fibers were found in clumps located just dorsal to the ventroposterior thalamic nucleus ; this labeling apparently originated from label in the fields of Forel , which extended around the medial border of the ventroposterior nucleus .
By the level of the AHA , there was only light label in the central medial and reuniens nuclei .
Additionally , the only robust labeling in the lateral hypothalamus at this level was found just medial to the internal capsule .
Periuentricular projection.
The CG was only lightly labeled , except for an area of heavier label ventral to nucleus Darkschewitsch and medial to the medial longitudinal fasciculus .
Labeling was clearly lighter rostral to the mainmillary bodies than it was more caudally.

With the exception of very strong labeling in the ipsilateral central medial thalamic nucleus , the dorsal periuentricular projection was light , particularly in the paraventricular thalamic nucleus .
The ventral component of the periventricular projection was also light .
Moderate labeling in the dorsal hypothalamic area was continuous laterally with label in the zona incerta .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Comparison of cases
Central gray injections Projections from injection sites centered in the mesencephalic CG follow two major trajectories.

The uentral prrr jection lies in the reticular formation; includes a number of decussating fibers; and contributes label to the peripeduncular area, substantia nigra, and other regions of the midbrain.

More rostrally, the ventral projection passes through the VTA and joins the MFB, distributing label to the hypothalamus, preoptic area, amygdala, ventral pallidum, substantia innominata, caudoputamen, and taenia tecta.
This ventral projection is light in case CG35, with an injection at the inferior collicular level.
By contrast, the rostral extent of the MFB and particularly the DBB are strongly labeled in case CG43, with an injection at the superior collicular level.

Case CG43 exhibits relatively heavier labeling in Forel's fields, the thalamic parafascicular nucleus, and the zona incerta, whereas cases with more caudal injection sites display stronger labeling in the VMN, supraoptic decussation, stria terminalis, and caudoputamen.

The dorsal component of the periventricular proJection distributes primarily to the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei, only lightly labeling the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus and entirely avoiding some nuclear groups.
The ventral component of the periventricular system follows a trajectory through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus and the dorsal hypothalamic area.
This projection apparently contributes to labeling in the dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus, perifornical region, and lateral septum.
Lateral injections Ascending - - proiections from iniections centered lateral I
to the mesencephalic CG are similar to those from injections in the CG; however, there are differences in both the details and the strength of projections.

In general, lateral injections provide relatively stronger labeling in the immediate vicinity of the application site, but contribute less strongly to the ventral and periventricular projection systems.

Moreover, with the exception of projections from the cuneiform nucleus to the VMN (cases CG39 and CG511, lateral injections distribute weaker projections to many limbic structures (e.g., the amygdala, hypothalamus, POA, and BNST).

All cases having lateral injections exhibit strong labeling contralaterally: heavily labeled fibers cross the midline in the posterior and collicular commissures and in the dorsal and ventral tegmental decussations.
In all lateral cases there is moderate to strong labeling of the supraoptic decussation, but only light to moderate labeling of the MFB.

In addition to labeling the VMN more heavily than its surround, cases with caudal injection sites (cases CG39 and CG51) both project to the lateral anteroventral thalamic nucleus and demonstrate a projection from the supraoptic decussation to the AHA and perifornical hypothalamus.
Although the ipsilateral central media1 nucleus is heavily labeled in case CG52, lateral injections generally provide relatively weak thalamic labeling.
Moreover, only case CG39 contributes strong labeling to the ventral periventricular system.
These comparisons indicate that the mediolateral placement of tracer influences the pattern of projections observed.
Some differences in projections also reflect the position of the injection site along the rostrocaudal extent of the mesencephalon.
For example, cases with injections in the caudal midbrain (cases CG35, CG39, CG51) provide particularly strong labeling of the supraoptic decussation.
By contrast, injections at the superior collicular level (cases CG43, CG52) clearly label Forel's fields, the zona incerta, and the thalamic parafascicular nucleus.
Thus, both the mediolateral and the rostrocaudal location of cells in the dorsal midbrain influence the pattern of ascending projections.
Comparison with other anatomical data

Studies using reduced silver methods to stain degenerated fibers (Kuypers, '56; Nauta, '58; Nauta and Kuypers, '58; Morest, '61) provide initial descriptions of projections from the midbrain CG of rats, rabbits, and cats.
These studies suggest two major features of CG projections.
One is the radiato grisea tegmenti, a radial pattern of fibers extending from the CG through the tegmentum, first described in normal material by Weisschedel ('37).
Degenerating axons from this radiation were traced as far rostrally as the lateral hypothalamus and preoptic area.
A second feature of CG efferents is the periventricular component, projecting to the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei and to the medial, periventricular, and dorsal hypothalamus.
Although not providing a complete description of ascending CG projections, these studies clearly demonstrate the strong interconnections between the CG and the limbic system.
More recent studies using modifications of the Nauta method provide further details of CG projections.

Working with cats, Hamilton and Skultety ('70) and Hamilton ('73) describe CG projections to the VTA, fields of Forel, pretectum, lateral habenula, and parafascicular thalamus; rostralmost projections are the posterior and periventricular hypothalamus.
These authors suggest that at least part of the radiatw grisea tegmerzti represents not neurons with cell bodies at the lesion site but rather damaged fibers of passage.
Chi C70), working with rats and cats, confirmed projections described previously and demonstrated CG projections to the zona incerta.
Yet, studies using degeneration techniques have not visualized projections to the ventral or medial hypothalamus or rostral to the preoptic area.
Because of the mode of axonal termination in the hypothalamus and the difficulty of impregnating very fine unmyelinated axons, these negative results must be interpreted with caution (Chi, '70).
Two autoradiographic studies describe CG efferents in cats (Ruda, '76) and squirrel monkeys (Mantyh, '83c,d).
Ruda ('76) confirms previous findings and describes projections to the AHA.

Mantyh ('83~) describes more extensive CG projections, including projections to the reticular thalamic nucleus, VMN, peri-arcuate hypothalamus, medial and lateral POA, substantia innominata, and medial globus pallidus.

Neither of these reports describes the relatively strong projection to the lateral habenula visualized in degeneration studies, suggesting that the robust habenular labeling described in previous studies may reflect damage to fibers of passage.
These autoradiographic studies indicate that projections from the midbrain CG are more extensive than previously demonstrated.
However, sensitive retrograde tracing techniques (e.g., see beginning of this paper) indicate projections not visualized in the autoradiographic studies of cats and monkeys.
The present study also provides evidence of more extensive projections than those demonstrated in cats and monkeys.
In particular, we observed a strong ventral projection pathway and widespread rostral projections from the CG.
These and other dissimilar findings may represent either veritable species differences, or differences in technique.
As indicated in the following section, numerous techniques were employed in the present study to increase the sensitivity of the autoradiographic method.

The pattern of projection most like that found from the CG in the present study is that from autoradiographic studies of the dorsal raphe nucleus (Conrad et al., '74; Taber Pierce et al., '76; Bobillier et al., '76; Azmitia and Segal, '78).
Projections from the CG appear to have a stronger periventricular component and a distinctly weaker projection to the hippocampal formation than that described in some studies of the dorsal raphe.
The similarity of projections may reflect, to some extent, the inclusion of nonraphe neurons in previous studies, and of raphe neurons in the present study.

Because the present study does not include cases with injections limited to the dorsal raphe, we cannot directly compare projections from injections limited to the raphe and those excluding all raphe neurons.

However, because the pattern of projections we observed was similar in all cases, not for only those labeling cells in the dorsal raphe, this explanation cannot fully account for the similarity of projections from the CG and from the dorsal raph6 nucleus.

Projections from injections lateral to the CG are similar to those described in autoradiographic studies of these lateral areas (Edwards and De Olmos, '76; Saper and Loewy, '80; Edley and Graybiel, '83).
It has been suggested (Hamilton, '73; Ruda, '76) that the CG of cats is composed of distinct regions, each having distinct efferent connections.
Mantyh ('83~) was unable to confirm this observation in squirrel monkeys.
The present study does not confirm this observation in rats.
However (as indicated in the following section), the present study was not designed to address this question.
In particular, we used relatively large injections of tracer.
Thus, we are unable to analyze CG projections in terms of position of the injection within the medial-lateral or dorsal-ventral extent of the CG.
Technical considerations

INng exposure period Because iontophoretic or pressure delivery of "H-leucine, 2-or 3-day survival periods, and exposure for 90 or 150 days resulted in only weak projections outside the injection site, the audioradiographic method was modified.
With extended exposures (21 months) strong projections may be seen (Fig. 5).
Although background labeling is higher, it does not obscure the signal.
Indeed, the ratio of apparent signal strength to background labeling is particularly high on slides exposed for 21 months.
3H-amino acid "cocktail" Several considerations suggest the potential advantages of using a cocktail of 'H-amino acids as a tracer.

First, there is evidence that ,%proline, a frequently used tracer, does not demonstrate the full range of projections from some regions (Kunzle and Cuknod, '73; Felix and Kiiryle, '74; Berkley, '75; Molinari and Berkley, '81).

However, "Hproline has characteristics that make its inclusion in a tracer advantageous: it is available with high specific activity, it is not readily taken up by the vascular system, it strongly labels some cells that are only lightly labeled by leucine, and it frequently provides stronger terminal labeling than does "H-leucine (Elam and Agranoff, '71; Kunzle and Cuenod, '73; Neale et al., '74; Edwards and Hendrickson, '81). pitiated leucine, perhaps the most widely used tracer for "H-amino acid autoradiography, also has distinct advantages: it is available with a high specific activity, is multiply incorporated into transported proteins, clearly labels axons, labels some projections not labeled by %proline, and is not heavily reutilized (Kiinzle and Cuenod, '73; Kiinzle, '75; Hunt and Kutule, '76; Heacock and Agranoff, '77; Edwards and Hendrickson, '81).
Tritiated tyrosine is rapidly taken up by cells (Guroff and Lovenberg, '70) and clearly labels cell bodies, axons, and terminals (Hunt and Kiinzle, '76).
Tritiated histidine is used in protein synthesis, but is not appreciably metabolized for reutilization (Guroff and Lovenberg, '70).

Moreover, histidine clearly accumulates in cells (Hunt and Kunzle, '761, perhaps being taken up by several transport mechanisms (Sershen and Lajtha, '79). l'ritiated lysine has also been suggested as a suitable tracer (Lasek, '75), and glycine, asparagine, methionine, and serine each have certain traits favoring their use as tracers.
Mechanisms of amino acid u take suggest a second adB ' vantage of using a cocktail of H-amino acids as a tracer.
Neurons accumulate amino acids from the extracellular space using different active transport mechanisms for amino acids with different chemical properties (Sershen and Lajtha, '79).

To minimize competition among amino acids using the same uptake mechanisms (Guroff, '72; Sershen and Lajtha, '79), we relied on classes of amino acids, (Lehninger, '78), based on the polarity of the R group, and chose amino acids from these different categories.
Equal volumes of L-isomers of tritiated proline, leucine, lysine, tyrosine, and histidine were pooled and used as a tracer.

Injections of the cocktail were made slowly (over 1.5-2 hours) to allow uptake of the tracer; the survival time was long (6 or 10 days) to allow for substantial incorporation and transport of the tracer.
Limitations methods used Injection sites.
A major goal of this study was to demonstrate distal projections from neurons in and adjacent to the mesencephalic CG.
For this reason, relatively large injections of tracer were made.
Several observations suggest that the inclusion of a small number of cells located lateral to the CG was of little significance.
First, in most cases, the injection site consists of a dense core containing many very heavily labeled cells, surrounded by a region with fewer cells that show much lighter labeling (Figs. 1, 3).
Consequently, in cases with injection sites centered in the CG it is likely that the heavily labeled cells (in the CG) contribute most strongly to the observed projections.
Second, cases with small injections entirely within the CG (e.g., case CG49) provide a pattern of labeling similar to, but lighter than, those with larger injection sites.
This observation suggests that lateral cells included in CG injections do not make important contributions to observed projections (see also Chi, '70).
Third, an indication of projections resulting from cells lateral to the CG may be had from cases with injection sites centered lateral to the CG.

Although providing heavier labeling in a number of areas (VMN, supraoptic decussation, mesencephalic reticular formation) and labeling many neurons some distance from the CG, lateral injections do not reveal projections unseen after CG injections.
Indeed, compared to CG injections, lateral injections provide generally weak labeling in distal regions rostra1 to the injection site.
Finally, by a number of criteria (see below), cells just lateral to the CG do not differ from those within the CG.

Thus, with the exception of neurons of mesencephalic V n, cells labeled by injections centered in the central gray may be more homogeneous than their position with respect to the border of the CG suggests.
Neurons of mesencephalic V n are not expected to contribute to ascending projections.
Cocktail tracer Inclusion of 'H-proline in the tracer raises the question
of artefactual labeling due to secondary transport of 3Hlabeled products (Grafstein, '71; Weisel et al., '74), particularly after long survival times (Landreth et al., '75).
Although secondary transport may have occurred in the present st.udy, it appears unlikely that it contributed materially to observed projections.

First, the pattern of pro'ec tions, including long projections, in cases receiving the A 11- cocktail tracer is very similar to projections, observed in cases receiving the 'H-leucine tracer (Figs. 3, 5, 6, 8, 9).
Second, if' there was significant secondary transport, one might expect to find labeled neurons some distance from the injection site.
These were not observed.
Third, Grafstein ('71) estimated that the amount of secondaiy transport in her material was about 2% of the primary projection.

Since 3H-proline represents only one of the five amino acids used in the tracer for this study, the amount of labeling reasonably attributable to secondary transport is negligible, certainly insufficient to account for the long projections observed.

The relatively long survival periods used in this study allow greater time for reutilization of 3H-labeled molecule:;, increasing the probability of secondary projections, as demonstrated by Weisel et al. ('74).

However, four considerations suggest that these conditions did not contribute substantially to secondary projections: (1) extending the survival period from 2 or 3 days to 6 or 10 days appears to increase the strength of long projections, but not to introduce new projections. (2) Compared to survival times used to demonstrate secondary projections (e.g., longer than 3 weeks by Weisel et al., '74), survival periods in the present experiment are relatively short. (3) Similarly, the levels of radioactivity used in this study (1.0 to 2.5 pCi) are very low compared to the heroic levels (3 mCi) used by Weisel et al. ('74) to demonstrate secondary projections. (4) Finally, studies indicating strong secondary projections (Weisel et al., '74; Drager, '74) use 3H-fucose in addition to 3H-proline.

The pattern of projections observed after injections of cocktail tracer and long survival times is similar to that observed after long exposure periods and in studies using retrograde tracers (see above).
Therefore, it seems likely that the extent of observed projections is not artefactual, but reflects the sensitivity of the autoradiographic method.
Functional considerations
The apparent distinction between cells located in the CG and those just lateral to it may be exaggerated by the annulus formed by fibers of the posterior and collicular commissures.
As determined by Golgi staining, the cytoarchitecture of CG neurons is reported to be very similar to that of neurons just lateral to the CG (Mantyh, '82a).
Additionally, neither afferent nor efferent connections of these two regions suggest a clear demarcation between them (Chi, '70; Morrell et al., '81; Beitz, '82; present study).

Moreover, the distribution of single units that do and do not respond to somatosensory and perigenital stimulation does not respect the borders of the CG (Malsbury et al., '72; Rose, '75, '82; Rose and Michael, '78).
Thus, in the following discussion, no distinction is made between cells in the CG and those just lateral to it.

Physiological and neurochemical data One function of CG neurons appears to be the processing or integration of sensory input: electrophysiological responses to somatosensory, visual, auditory, and noxious stimuli have been recorded from the CG (Kerr et al., '55; Hara et al., '61: Liebeskind and Mayer, '71).
Indeed, single units in the CG respond to somatosensory stimuli resembling those that trigger estrous behavior (Malsbury et al., '72; Rose, '75).
A second function of CG neurons seems to be the modulation of behavior.

Electrical stimulation or lesions of the mammalian CG may alter sexual behavior (Sakuma and Pfaff, '79a,b; Rose and Smucker, '82), nociception (Spiegel et al., '54; Delgado, '55; reviewed in Fields and Basbaum, '78; Watkins and Mayer, '821, affective or emotional reactions CMagoun et al., '37; Hess and Akert, '55; Hunsperger, '59; reviewed in Skultety, '631, escapeiavoidance performance (Stein, '65; Halpern, '681, vocalization (Jurgens and Pratt, '79; Floody and O'Donohue, '80), and neuroendocrine responses (Carrer and Taleisnik, '70, '72; Johnson et al., '81).

Microinjections of opioid agonists and antagonists, peptides, or putative neurotransmitters into the CG influence sexual behavior (Riskind and Moss, '79; Sakuma and Pfaff, '80; Zadina et al., '81; Sirinathsinghji et al., '831, nociception (Pert and Yaksh, '74; Sherman and Gebhart, '76; reviewed in Basbaum and Fields, '78, '841, behavioral reactivity (Jacquet and Lajtha, '73, '74; Sharpe et al., '741, and serum hormone levels (Zakoski and Gebhart, '82).
Thus, there is clear evidence that CG neurons respond to sensory stimuli and may have widespread influences on behavior.
Neurochemically, the CG appears to be sufficiently heterogeneous to subserve diverse functions.

Both opioid receptors (Hiller et al., '73; Kuhar et al., '73; Pert et al., '76) and estrogen-concentrating neurons (Pfaff and Keiner, '73; Stumpf et al., '75) are present in the CG, as are neuronal cell bodies, fibers, and apparent terminals containing many neuroactive substances.

Biochemical and immunocytochemical studies indicate the presence in the CG of enkephalin (Elde et al., '76; Hokfelt et al., '77a,b; Simantov et al., '77; Watson et al., '771, dynorphin (Gramsch et al., '82; Khachaturian et al., '821, &endorphin (Bloom et al., '78; Dupont et al., '801, corticotropin-releasing factor (Merchenthaler et al., '82; Olschowka et al., '82), cholecystokinin (Beinfeld and Palkovits, '821, a-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (Dube et al., '78; Jacobowitz and O'Donohue, '78), neurotensin (Uhl et al., '791, luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (Silverman and Krey, '78; Samson et al., '801, vasoactive intestinal peptide (Sims et al., '80), choline acetyltransferase (Kimura et al., '811, monoamines (Dahlstrom and Fuxe, '65; Ungerstedt, '711, prolactin (Harlan et al., '831, neurophysin (Swanson, '771, and substance P (Hokfelt et al., '77; Cuello and Kanazawa, '78).
The presence of these substances in the CG suggests that diverse neurochemical systems may influence CG neurons, thereby modifying a broad range of functions.
Anatomical data Studies of "emotional" behavior have focused on the CG and more rostra1 periventricular structures (e.g., Hess and Akert, '55; Hunsperger '59; Skultety, '63).

The robust projections from the CG to these periventricular structures (Figs. 3, 5, 6, 81, as well as to other areas of the limbic system (e.g., central nucleus of the amygdala, lateral septum, POA, hypothalamus, stria terminalis), provide an anatomical substrate for participation in "emotional" reactions.

Most of the recent attention directed to CG participation in the control of nociception (reviewed in Fields and Basbaum, '78; Dubner and Bennett, '83) and reproductive behavior (reviewed in Pfaff, '80, '83) has focused on descending projections.

However, both physiological and neurochemical evidence suggests that ascending projections from the midbrain CG may influence distress vocalizations (Herman and Panksepp, '81) and the transmission of nociceptive input (Andersen and Dafny, '83; Reigle, '85).

Further evidence suggesting a role for ascending projections from the CG in the control of nociception includes the following: studies of the spinothalamic tract describe clear projections to the CG (e.g., Clark, '36; Mehler et al., '60; Kerr, '75; Boivie, '79).

Not only does the CG receive projections from spinal fibers carrying input from noxious stimuli (Mehler, '66, '74; Kerr, '75), but some neurons in the CG respond to such stimuli (Hara et al., '61; Nashold et al., '74).
Moreover, fibers carrying nociceptive input project to intralaminar thalamic nuclei receiving CG projections (Clark, '36; Per1 and Whitlock, '61; Boivie, '79; Mantyh, '83a,b; present study).
Thus, the strong projection from the CG to the intralaminar thalamus may carry, or modify, nociceptive input to these thalamic areas (see also Mantyh, '83~).
In addition, robust projections to the limbic system provide an anatomical substrate for activating an affective component of pain responding.
